---
layout: post
title: Scala actors design patterns - state machines
created: 1295874063
author: ittayd
permalink: /incubator/scala-actors-design-patterns-state-machines
tags:
- Incubator
- Scala
---
<p>Scala actors can encode state machines in a very easy way.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Take for example this state transition.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img style="width: 416px; height: 71px;" src="data:image/png;base64," alt="" /></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Using actors, the state transitions are created using messages. So an actor for this state transition will look like:</p>
<pre class="brush: scala;" title="code">
actor {
  // in state a. do stuff
  react {
    case A() =&gt; 
      // state b. do stuff
      react {
        case B() =&gt; 
          // state c. do stuff
      }
  }
}
</pre>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Of course, messages can carry data. Then that data is visible in subsequent states.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>A similar diagram where the actor returns from 'c' to 'a' can be created by using 'loop' as the first statement.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>What about more complex interactions?&nbsp;Consider:</p>
<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," style="width: 396px; height: 131px;" /></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>What we can use here is the fact that 'react' is not&nbsp; a normal method. It doesn't return control to its caller, but throws an exception that is handled by the framework (the exception is very light weight - it is a constant value with no stack trace filling)</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<pre class="brush: scala;" title="code">
actor {
  def a = {
    // do stuff
    react {
      case A() =&gt; b
    }
  }
 
  def b = {
    // do stuff
    react {
      case B() =&gt; c
    }
  }

  def c = {
    // do stuff
    react {
      case D() =&gt; b
      case E() =&gt; a
    }
  }

  a
}

</pre>
<p>Each state is a method (of course this is optional as we saw in the first case). Calling the methods looks like recursion, but is actually not. And like before, there's no reason not to pass arguments to these methods.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>That's it. HTH</p>
<pre class="brush: scala;" title="code">

</pre>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
